image.altText: A man in a suit looking down

items.synopsis: Ben Roberts-Smith resigns from his job at Seven West Media, as the company's billionaire chairman Kerry Stokes says the imputations found to be true in yesterday's crushing court judgement do "not accord with the man I know".

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith resigns from Seven as war crimes judgement reverberates around globe

image.altText: A tall man in military uniform speaks with Queen Elizabeth in an ornate room

items.synopsis: Once a hero to politicians and civilians alike, a court found the 44-year-old's reputation is now so lowered that two unproven allegations of battlefield murder weren't enough to defame him.

title.children: From 'Australian hero' to 'disgracing' his country — inside a decorated soldier's massive fall

image.altText: Bill Shorten standing in front of a NDIS logo

items.synopsis: The federal government is working on a new law to explicitly make it illegal to charge more for products and services because a client is on the National Disability Insurance Scheme.

title.children: 'Shouldn't view the NDIS as a chance to build a verandah on their beach house': Government announces crackdown on inflated prices for NDIS services

image.altText: Dirt flows from a hole in a metal construction wall underground.

items.synopsis: No workers were injured in a minor underground collapse on the road tunnel project in Melbourne's inner west.

title.children: Workers evacuated after tunnel collapse hundreds of metres underground on major Melbourne project

image.altText: an infrared image of two white bodies with waving arms against a black background

items.synopsis: A 13-year-old boy and his teacher have been rescued in south-west Victorian by helicopter following becoming disoriented during a school camp.

title.children: Lost student and teacher found in Victorian bush, winched to safety in night rescue

items.synopsis: Australia's minimum wage lifts by 8.6 per cent, award workers get 5.75 per cent increase, in Fair Work Commission decision.

title.children: Australia's minimum wage jumps by 8.6 per cent, award workers get 5.75 per cent pay boost

image.altText: Daniel Andrews speaking

items.synopsis: The Victorian government walks back plans to hit 110 private schools with payroll tax, with Premier Daniel Andrews conceding the policy will not raise as much money as forecast in last week's state budget.

title.children: Premier Daniel Andrews walks back controversial private school payroll tax change

image.altText: Several photographers point cameras at a man, who is standing, looking on.

items.synopsis: The Australian War Memorial says it will continue to display disgraced war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith's uniform and medals for now, but will consider adding context.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith's memorabilia to remain on display at Australian War Memorial

image.altText: Peter Dutton wearing black glasses standing in front of a blurry australian flag looking straight toward the camera

items.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says the court ruling against decorated war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith was a "tough day for the country" and believes there has been a "significant culture change" at the Australian Defence Force.

title.children: Dutton says Roberts-Smith ruling a 'tough day for our country' as Taliban alleges there were 'uncountable crimes'

image.altText: A man taking a selfie with a mobile phone

items.synopsis: Danny Zayat is facing 18 domestic violence charges against his former partner, whose body was found inside her Liverpool unit last week.

title.children: Lawyer argues domestic violence case weakened due to complainant being deceased

image.altText: A line of police, some armed, standing behind plastic wrapped packaged piles of cocaine.

items.synopsis: Police find 29 packages of the drug hidden onboard a bulk cargo carrier bound for Western Australia, in one of the largest cocaine busts in decades.

title.children: Police seize 800kg of cocaine from bulk carrier in one of Australia's biggest-ever drug busts

image.altText: Daniel Ben Barnett pleaded guilty to seven domestic violence offenders.

items.synopsis: Daniel Ben Barnett will spend at least 16 months in jail for domestic violence offences, with the sentencing magistrate noting his actions had intruded on the victim's life in every aspect.

title.children: Man jailed for tracking ex-lover's car, bugging her home

image.altText: Kitchen worker uses tongs in a pub kitchen in Sydney.

items.synopsis: A 5.75 per cent boost to award wages is massive and will affect millions of workers. But inflation means they'll still have less to spend, writes Daniel Ziffer.

title.children: Wages rise but sorry, you're probably still going backwards

image.altText: US Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer gives a thumbs up and smiles.

items.synopsis: The US Senate passes bipartisan legislation backed by President Joe Biden that lifts the government's $31.4 trillion debt ceiling, averting what would have been a first-ever default.

title.children: US averts historic default with 11th-hour deal to lift debt ceiling

image.altText: Players stand together as they pose for a team photo

items.synopsis: The Adelaide Thunderbirds were the first team to host an Indigenous game at the national level in 2013. One of their foundation players from 16 years prior says more can be done to recognise the club's past First Nations talent, writes Brittany Carter.

title.children: Ten years on, Thunderbirds showcase their cultural leadership during First Nations Round

image.altText: Australian banknotes, mostly $50 bills, strewn over a flat surface.

items.synopsis: The government's proposal is expected to increase the pay of about 2 per cent of its workforce. These charts show exactly who those staff are.

title.children: Which public servants will receive salary boosts under the plan to fix pay gaps?

image.altText: A media scrum surrounds Mark McGowan's car

items.synopsis: Outgoing premier Mark McGowan receives a rock star reception from waiting media as he arrives for his final day in the state's top job, insisting he has no regrets.

title.children: 'I'm going to watch some Netflix': Mark McGowan has no regrets on his final day as WA premier

image.altText: Four mobile phones in various states of disrepair are pieced by rusty nails to the trunk of a tree

items.synopsis: In a basement in a Ukrainian village on the Russian border, the remnants of a torture chamber tell a horrifying tale. Those investigating what happened here say the depraved orders came from the top. WARNING: Readers might find the details in this story distressing.

title.children: When Russians arrived in this village, they nailed all the phones to a tree. Then locals say the torture began

image.altText: A group of solar panels on a roof through the frame of leafy trees.

items.synopsis: Rocketing power prices have reignited interest in rooftop solar, but are low feed-in tariffs discouraging people from taking the plunge?

title.children: Claims of 'rip-off' as solar feed-in tariffs plummet even as power prices soar

image.altText: A close-up photo of a young man wearing a collared shirt and tie.

items.synopsis: A phone call made by 20-year-old Kobee Huddy to a mental health support line hours before he was shot in Adelaide's west after threatening police has been played to a coronial inquest into his death. WARNING: The following article contains details that may distress some readers.

title.children: Helpline operator told man she had no 'magical advice' hours before he was shot dead by police

image.altText: A man outside an Adelaide court with his lawyer.

items.synopsis: Two members of a neo-Nazi group found with instructions on how to carry out a terrorist attack have been sentenced to more than two years behind bars.

title.children: Neo-Nazi group members jailed for 'abhorrent and distressing' crimes

image.altText: An island resort that is now over grown and run down

items.synopsis: Developer Benny Wu is at the centre of legal action over a dilapidated former destination for Hollywood stars as he faces further scrutiny over other run-down properties in Queensland's far north.

title.children: Hong Kong billionaire may lose tropical Queensland island 'jewel' as properties fall into disrepair

image.altText: A speaker thrusts his arm into the air as thousands of unionists look on at the Domain in Sydney

items.synopsis: The Fair Work Commission announces a 5.75 per cent increase in award wages, while the US Senate votes to suspend the debt ceiling days before the US risked default. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US Senate passes debt ceiling deal and we answer your questions on Australia's award wage increase

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There is no shortage for business and financial related news this Friday, let me tell you! While we were busy digesting the Fair Work Commission's minimum wage decision, the Bureau of Statistics released some new lending indicators data — aka the number and value of new housing loans. In April, there was a 2.9% fall in the rate of new loans being taken out, after a rise of 5.3% in March (which was the first rise in 14 months). The ABS figures also show there were fewer first home buyers who purchased a home, with the value of first home buyer loans down by 2.1% in April, and 16.4% over the year. There was also a drop in the rate of people refinancing to a new lender. That dropped by 9.2% since March —making it the largest monthly decrease since November 2020.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fall in new mortgages being taken out in April, ABS data shows

children.content: There is no shortage for business and financial related news this Friday, let me tell you!
While we were busy digesting the Fair Work Commission's minimum wage decision, the Bureau of Statistics released some new lending indicators data — aka the number and value of new housing loans.
In April, there was a 2.9% fall in the rate of new loans being taken out, after a rise of 5.3% in March (which was the
first rise in 14 months).
The ABS figures also show there were fewer first home buyers who purchased a home, with the value of first home buyer loans down by 2.1% in April, and 16.4% over the year.
There was also a drop in the rate of people refinancing to a new lender.
That dropped by 9.2% since March —making it the largest monthly decrease since November 2020.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US Senate has passed a bill to suspend the $US 31.4 trillion debt ceiling, averting the risk of a default. The Senate voted 63-36 to approve the bill that was passed yesterday by the House of Representatives, as lawmakers raced against the clock following months of partisan bickering between Democrats and Republicans. The Treasury Department had warned it would be unable to pay all its bills on June 5 if Congress failed to act by then. The debt ceiling will be suspended until January 1, 2025. The bill now goes to US President Joe Biden to sign into law.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: US debt ceiling bill passes Senate

children.content: The US Senate has passed a bill to suspend the $US 31.4 trillion debt ceiling, averting the risk of a default.

The Senate voted 63-36 to approve the bill that was passed yesterday by the House of Representatives, as lawmakers raced against the clock following months of partisan bickering between Democrats and Republicans.
The Treasury Department had warned it would be unable to pay all its bills on June 5 if Congress failed to act by then.
The debt ceiling will be suspended until January 1, 2025.
The
bill now goes to US President Joe Biden to sign into law.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: For those of you desperate to keep up with the latest market news, apologies for the wages distraction. But the Fair Work Commission (FWC) award wages decision does seem to have had some influence on the ASX. From an early high of 7,166 around 10:12am AEST, around the time the FWC handed down its wages determination, the ASX 200 index has steadily pared back its gains to 7,131 points. That is still up 0.3% on yesterday's close, but well off the S & P 500's 1% gain on Wall Street overnight. There are two reasons why a higher than expected award wage increase may have had this effect: It will push up costs for businesses who pay their employees award rates or whose enterprise agreements are benchmarked off the award. Some economists believe it will raise pressure on the Reserve Bank to raise interest rates again, possibly as soon as next week. That seems to be reflected in the sectors gaining and losing ground. Mining, utilities and energy are up — they are much more affected by global pricing forces, with wages a smaller share of costs and most of their workforces above award rates anyway. Consumer non-cyclicals (dominated by the big supermarkets), financials and healthcare are down. These are labour intensive sectors, with many employees either on award rates or on enterprise agreements that are not a huge amount above award rates, so many of these firms are likely to see their costs rise substantially as a result of today's decision.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX clings to gains mid-session

children.content: For those of you desperate to keep up with the latest market news, apologies for the wages distraction.
But the Fair Work Commission (FWC) award wages decision does seem to have had some influence on the ASX.
From an early high of 7,166 around 10:12am AEST, around the time the FWC handed down its wages determination,
the ASX 200 index has steadily pared back its gains to 7,131 points
That is still
up 0.3% on yesterday's close
, but well off the S
P 500's 1% gain on Wall Street overnight.
There are two reasons why a higher than expected award wage increase may have had this effect:
It will push up costs for businesses who pay their employees award rates or whose enterprise agreements are benchmarked off the award.
Some economists believe it will raise pressure on the Reserve Bank to raise interest rates again, possibly as soon as next week.
That seems to be reflected in the sectors gaining and losing ground.
Mining, utilities and energy are up
— they are much more affected by global pricing forces, with wages a smaller share of costs and most of their workforces above award rates anyway.
Consumer non-cyclicals (dominated by the big supermarkets), financials and healthcare are down
These are
labour intensive sectors

, with many employees either on award rates or on enterprise agreements that are not a huge amount above award rates, so many of these firms are likely to see their costs rise substantially as a result of today's decision.

items.synopsis: A lot of people think dogs eat grass when they have a sore stomach, believing grass causes dogs to vomit. But this is probably not the case, write Susan Hazel and Joshua Zoanetti.

title.children: Why does my dog eat grass? And when is it unsafe?
